headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Nordstrom First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.At this time, I will turn the call over to Trina Schurman. Director of Investor Relations for Nordst
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the Nordstrom First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
At this time, I will turn the call over to Trina Schurman. Director of Investor Relations for Nordstrom. You may begin.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.Before we begin, I want to mention that we'll be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com i
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.
Before we begin, I want to mention that we'll be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com in the Investor Relations section. Our discussion may include forward-looking statements, so please refer to the slide showing our safe harbor language.
Participating in today's call is Blake Nordstrom, Co-President. He will discuss the company's first quarter performance and the outlook for fiscal year 2017. Joining during the Q&A session will be Pete and Erik Nordstrom, Co-Presidents; Jamie Nordstrom, President of Stores; and Jim Powell, Executive Vice President of Finance and Treasurer.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Blake.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. Before we review our first quarter results, I'd like to provide some context about how our business has evolved and the direction we're heading. Over the past decade, we transitioned from being a predominantly mall-based store bu
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. Before we review our first quarter results, I'd like to provide some context about how our business has evolved and the direction we're heading. Over the past decade, we transitioned from being a predominantly mall-based store business to one that is more diversified, with multiple ways for customers to shop with us. During this time, we've invested in capabilities to better serve our customers and gain market share. This fueled our e-commerce growth, increased our customer base and enabled us to expand into new markets. Through these efforts, we've added nearly $6 billion to our top line. 
In keeping our customers at the forefront of everything we do, our business looks very different today. Nearly 1 quarter of our sales are from online purchases compared to roughly 5% from 10 years ago. We've added more ways to serve customers through our acquisitions of Trunk Club and HauteLook. Nordstromrack.com and HauteLook are on track to be our fastest-growing business to reach $1 billion. We offer a variety of services that support our customers' needs around convenience such as buy online, pickup in store, curbside pickup and same-day delivery. We continued to invest in critical talent and capabilities around technology, mobile, data analytics and supply chain. Our local market assets, our stores, salespeople, product and services represent the core of our brand. We're fortunate to have a high-quality portfolio of 122 full-line stores with all of our comp stores generating positive cash flow. Furthermore, our stores play an important role in attracting and retaining customers. Nearly 80% of customers who shop with us across multiple channels began at our full-line or Rack stores.
We've strategically grown our off-price business, which represents roughly 30% of sales. It's positioned as our largest source of new customers with the average age skewing younger than our overall business. About 1/3 of customers who start shopping at the Rack will also cross shop in our full price business. We believe this is a unique competitive advantage in the market.
Because our customer shopping experience maybe influenced by multiple touch points, it's important that we view our business from the perspective of the markets in which we serve them. We're finding than measuring our outcomes through discrete channel metrics such as store comps are becoming less relevant.
As we continue to head in this direction, we're increasingly looking at our business as full-price and off-price, inclusive of stores and online, to better capture the synergies of having a physical and digital presence.
Now I'd like to discuss our first quarter results. Our earnings were in line with our expectations. We reported earnings per diluted share of $0.37, which included a onetime charge of $0.06 associated with the $650 million debt refinancing in the first quarter.
Last year, earnings per share of $0.26 included a $0.10 charge primarily related to higher credit chargebacks as we transitioned to a change in industry liability rules. When excluding these charges, our first quarter earnings increased 19% on a comparable basis.
While we're pleased with our inventory and expense execution, we're not satisfied with our top line results. Total sales increased 2.7% while comps decreased 0.8%. This was generally consistent with the trends we've experienced over the past year. 
In our full-price business, total sales decreased 1.7% and comps decreased 2.8%. From a merchandise perspective, we had strengthen our men's and women's apparel while accessories remained soft. Our expansion and full-price gross margin reflected the continued strength of our regular price sales. 
Our focus on expanding product with limited distribution helps us provide customers with the most sought-after brands while mitigating our business from the promotional environment. These efforts contributed to 100 basis point increase in the mix of regular price sales and our full-price business.
In our off-price business, total sales increased 8.7% and comps increased 2.3%. We took additional markdowns on slower-moving items, which impacted gross margins. Overall, our gross profit rate was slightly up from last year. We ended the quarter with inventory growth in line with sales growth.
Moving to our 2017 outlook. Our plan is grounded in the sales trends we've experienced over the past year. We are reiterating our earnings per share range of $2.75 to $3, total sales growth of 3% to 4% and approximately flat comps.
As we look ahead, we have a number of opportunities to drive growth. From a merchandising perspective, we continue to focus on providing customers with newness through a greater emphasis on limited distribution and relevant product. Our long-term ambition is for continued double-digit online growth. We've been able to increase the speed and agility with which we roll out enhancements to our product pages, navigation and content.
Mobile is integral to the customer's shopping experience and accounts for more than half of our online traffic. We're continuing testing and rolling out new ways to connect the physical and digital experiences. As an example, we're expanding reserve online and trying in stores from 60 to 50 stores this year. 
This fall, we have our 6 full-line store opening in Canada at [ Sureway ] Gardens in Toronto and 2 full-lines to a relocations in California at Westfield Century City in Los Angeles and at University Town Center in La Jolla. We have opened 6 Racks so far in 2017 and have 11 more opening in the fall. Additionally, we're excited about our Manhattan flagship, which is on track to be completed in 2019.
We recently announced a phased approach with the men's store opening first in spring 2018. 
Finally, I'd like to share that we're looking forward to having [ Anne Bremann ] join our team as CFO on June 2. She brings extensive retail experience with demonstrated success as a business partner and a steward of capital. Anne is succeeding Mike Koppel, who retired at the beginning of this month. Over the past 16 years, Mike has provided insight to the leadership team into how we can best utilize the company's resources to produce the outcomes we aspire to achieve. Our financial standing and overall reputation have been greatly enhanced by his leadership. And first, I'd like to thank Mike for his many contributions.
I'll now turn it over to Trina for Q&A.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Blake. [Operator Instructions] We will now move to the Q&A session.
componenttext: Thank you, Blake. [Operator Instructions] We will now move to the Q&A session.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Matthew Boss with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Matthew Boss with JPMorgan.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: So my question is can you talk a little bit about the Rack? So total off-price comps in the quarter slowed to, I think, the worst trend in around 3 years. Was this a result of lower traffic? Any changes in competition? And then on the higher off-price mar
componenttext: So my question is can you talk a little bit about the Rack? So total off-price comps in the quarter slowed to, I think, the worst trend in around 3 years. Was this a result of lower traffic? Any changes in competition? And then on the higher off-price markdowns, how much did this actually pressure the gross margin in the quarter?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Matthew, this is Blake. Let's talk about our off-price business. In terms of the Rack, we had a 0.9% decrease. Our plans were to be flat. So we're really close to that. But to be clear, our plan is to beat that. Our goal is to be ahead of our plans, and s
componenttext: Matthew, this is Blake. Let's talk about our off-price business. In terms of the Rack, we had a 0.9% decrease. Our plans were to be flat. So we're really close to that. But to be clear, our plan is to beat that. Our goal is to be ahead of our plans, and so we recognized that we had some opportunities. There were a number of things that our team is working on, but there isn't any one thing that I would call out. It's not dissimilar to the performance we had in Q4. We where down 0.8%. So we have seen a little bit of a softening, but it is close to our plan and we are encouraged by the opportunities and then [indiscernible] we have for the balance of this year. In terms of the online off-price portion of it, it also just missed our plans. We're anniversarying from a year ago, the strongest numbers we had. We had a 42% increase a year ago in Q1 in online off-price. We had a 19% performance for Q1 of 2017, and that just missed our plan. And you'll see as the balance of the year goes on, much stronger numbers with our plan because we have a plan for the year that is stronger weighted towards the balance end of the year. In terms of your specifics that we've seen anything from competition or other factors, we don't have anything material that we would point out, only that we recognize this fell short of our goals and we got work to do to improve upon that. You had, I think, a question on the margin, too. Regarding Q1 margins, I did call out in my remarks that we took higher markdowns in our Rack business predominantly due to some seasonal underperforming merchandise. We had some more boots and coats and other things that we felt necessitated some more markdowns. That had an impact to the overall. The overall margin was relatively flat. Full-price had an improvement in margin with off-price bringing it down slightly.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Next is Mark Altschwager with Robert W. Baird and Company.
componenttext: Next is Mark Altschwager with Robert W. Baird and Company.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask on the SG&A side. Can you just give us a sense of where you're having the most excess spending the cost curve there? Any timing issues impacting the results this quarter? And just more broadly, how you're thinking about your SG&A growth ou
componenttext: I wanted to ask on the SG&A side. Can you just give us a sense of where you're having the most excess spending the cost curve there? Any timing issues impacting the results this quarter? And just more broadly, how you're thinking about your SG&A growth outlook for the remainder of the year?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Blake, and I'll start, then I might have is Jim weigh in if I missed some things. Again, we made some comments in both the slide, I believe, and in my comments that technology was a little bit higher. And that was planned. That will level out thro
componenttext: This is Blake, and I'll start, then I might have is Jim weigh in if I missed some things. Again, we made some comments in both the slide, I believe, and in my comments that technology was a little bit higher. And that was planned. That will level out throughout the year, so that had an impact from a timing point of view for Q1. There have been, throughout last year, a number of initiatives to get our SG&A in line with the business performance. We've been working really hard on that model, and we think that's starting to bear some fruit and that's showed both in the Q3, Q4 and this earnings where we're seeing improved SG&A expense management. So Jim, is there any other thing that you'd call out?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ed Yruma with KeyBanc Capital Market.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ed Yruma with KeyBanc Capital Market.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: So with 23% of your business online, I know that you guys have kind of rearchitected your investment in the full-price stores to focus on some of the higher-volume doors. I appreciate the comment you gave about the cash flow of all stores, but how do you
componenttext: So with 23% of your business online, I know that you guys have kind of rearchitected your investment in the full-price stores to focus on some of the higher-volume doors. I appreciate the comment you gave about the cash flow of all stores, but how do you think about the profitability of some of the lower-volume full-line stores? And how has that changed over time?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'll take that. Ed, it's Jamie. Yes, I would say we transitioned our practice of investing in remodels from historically, it was a pretty democratic approach where after 10 or 12 years, we remodel a store kind of regardless of the volume level of performa
componenttext: I'll take that. Ed, it's Jamie. Yes, I would say we transitioned our practice of investing in remodels from historically, it was a pretty democratic approach where after 10 or 12 years, we remodel a store kind of regardless of the volume level of performance. And over the last couple of years has transitioned to making more strategic investments in our highest volume stores. These are stores that we think play a bigger role in creating our brand. When it comes to our smaller volume stores, yes, they do generate cash. Like I said, all of our stores are cash flow positive, and we make money there. Obviously, if you do it -- put a bunch of capital into it, that can change that picture. We think we've got a lot of opportunities in the middle, frankly. It's not so much that the small [indiscernible] stores, we think those will be fine. It's a lot of the stores in the middle that we have an opportunity to upgrade them. So we're looking at a lot of different alternatives. We're working with our partners on the real estate side of big mall developers out there that we're partners with that are as motivated as we are to upgrade those stores. So we're starting to work on that, and we think we'll start to see some progress later this year.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me jump in. This is Erik. What I'd add to that is increasingly, what's appropriate for us is to look at this business as just as 1 channel, which means for store reinvestment looking at the online impact that a store has an really giving our stor
componenttext: Yes. Let me jump in. This is Erik. What I'd add to that is increasingly, what's appropriate for us is to look at this business as just as 1 channel, which means for store reinvestment looking at the online impact that a store has an really giving our stores have local asset that we can leverage. So as we get better data on the influences that go into customer behavior, that includes both digital experiences and physical store experiences, that better informed decisions like how much capital put into stores as opposed to just looking at the four-wall contribution of that 1 store.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Next is Adrienne Yih with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Next is Adrienne Yih with Wolfe Research.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: My question is on sort of the real estate backdrop and things that we're seeing. Can you talk about what you think the ideal footprint for both full-line and then Nordstrom Rack is perhaps in the next 3- to 5-year horizon? And then secondarily, it would s
componenttext: My question is on sort of the real estate backdrop and things that we're seeing. Can you talk about what you think the ideal footprint for both full-line and then Nordstrom Rack is perhaps in the next 3- to 5-year horizon? And then secondarily, it would seem like men's and women's apparel kind of leading the leading categories. I'm wondering if you could talk about the fashion backdrop? And whether we don't talk about that much these days, but the fashion cycle is kind of in there in the background and it seems to be tightening in early spring. I wonder if could just talk about merchandising there? And where you think that has led to drive some of the business in the fall season?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Adrienne, it's Jamie. I'll take the first part around the stores. For full-line stores, we have roughly 120 stores today. It's a healthy fleet. And as Erik pointed out, we're really looking at how those stores help to drive our sales in every given market
componenttext: Adrienne, it's Jamie. I'll take the first part around the stores. For full-line stores, we have roughly 120 stores today. It's a healthy fleet. And as Erik pointed out, we're really looking at how those stores help to drive our sales in every given market. While there maybe opportunities to close underperforming stores, that's not really part of our strategy. We don't have a closures strategy. We have a market share strategy. So as we look at any given market, there might be an opportunity to move from a C location to an A location as an example. There might be opportunities to look at the number of stores we have in any given market, but what we're not going to look at this just simply the four-wall economics of that store. We're going to look at how good a job we're doing using and leveraging those stores to drive overall market sales. You want to take the right one?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: You bet. This is Blake, and I just would add before I talk about the Rack. In addition to the footprint, I mentioned that we're opening in Sureway in Toronto, we've got 2 relocations. We've gotten the [ half ] coming out and then are 1 or 2 other tentativ
componenttext: You bet. This is Blake, and I just would add before I talk about the Rack. In addition to the footprint, I mentioned that we're opening in Sureway in Toronto, we've got 2 relocations. We've gotten the [ half ] coming out and then are 1 or 2 other tentative ones. We're not looking at other store locations within full-line stores outside what Jamie said in terms of enhancing what we have or maybe a relocation. We think we have the right footprint to best serve the country. So we're pleased with our store locations. In terms of the Rack, we ended last year with 215 stores. We've talked about in the past that we could, over time, have approximately 300. I think the important thing there, too, is also the digital side of it. We ended last year with NordstromRack.com and HauteLook with $700 million sales. I made reference in my comments that this is the fastest-growing part of our business. It is true this company is moving towards $1 billion. So we're particularly excited from an off-price point of view what's possible in digital very similar to what's happening in full price.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: And this is Pete. I'll take the part about the fashion cycle. I think that the teams that are generally true across all classifications is that you -- is the continuing turnaround cash realization that we need to be mindful of really kind of across the bo
componenttext: And this is Pete. I'll take the part about the fashion cycle. I think that the teams that are generally true across all classifications is that you -- is the continuing turnaround cash realization that we need to be mindful of really kind of across the board and that we've had good success I think where we focus on that appropriately. Newness is always a theme that we talk about. And for us to have our inventories in line and be able to bring new goods in always helps stimulate the business. Also athletic and fitness type brands, and that's part of that cash realization lifestyle part that we talked about a bit over the years. That's a strong trend. If you look at our top brands, it's interesting. We have several that are super healthy and growing double digits, and we have some big legacy brands we've done this that are not that are shrinking quite [indiscernible]. So I guess, that's always been true to a degree but the good news for us is that with -- how some of the brands are falling off, it creates open to buy for us. And so if you look at it from a buyer's point of view and our whole merchandising team, I think they feel pretty energized about the opportunity to go out and either apply more resources to some of these positive trends or find new brands. I think generally, our team feels that is the nature of our business, but feels kind of optimistic about the future and our ability to be able to find great product.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Next is Paul Lejuez with Citi.
componenttext: Next is Paul Lejuez with Citi.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Going back to the gross margin line for a second. Just curious one on the March margin, specifically what did full price look like year-over-year just relative to itself? Same question for Rack. And I'm just curious if you can provide any more detail abou
componenttext: Going back to the gross margin line for a second. Just curious one on the March margin, specifically what did full price look like year-over-year just relative to itself? Same question for Rack. And I'm just curious if you can provide any more detail about what happened in 1Q at Rack? Was there any change in terms of the percentage of inventory that it was taking from full price? Did that have an any impact on anything? If you can add any color there, it would be great.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, this is Jim. On the margin side, I think you have to remember, last year first quarter, sales were pretty tough. And we were a little bit of out of line with our inventories when we talked about that last year. And so we did see improvement in the f
componenttext: Okay, this is Jim. On the margin side, I think you have to remember, last year first quarter, sales were pretty tough. And we were a little bit of out of line with our inventories when we talked about that last year. And so we did see improvement in the full-price margins just by virtue of the tougher comparison. I think the back half of this year will be more normalized because if you'll recall, last year, in the back half, we did a nice job and we're still holding inventories pretty well. On the off-price side, I think Blake's comments covered it. I think there were some pockets of good that we had to take markdowns on, but I don't know that there's anything that we're -- anything broader that we're seeing that concerns us.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's one other thing on the off-price, which I think speaks to the dynamic of how the multiple channels work together. So we had such great growth in the online part of our off-price business, but the resulting action of that kind of the unintende
componenttext: Yes, there's one other thing on the off-price, which I think speaks to the dynamic of how the multiple channels work together. So we had such great growth in the online part of our off-price business, but the resulting action of that kind of the unintended consequence, it creates more returns into a physical Rack stores, except that someone brought online, customers often choose -- actually most often choose the one  returned out of store. So we've got the more inventory back into the store than we had originally planned. And that's again because of the large growth that we've had there on the online part of the business and in off-price part of the segment. So we can adjust to that as it goes forward, but we're playing catch up on that a little bit. And I think we understand the further along that we get how to anticipate those inventory conditions and so that we can do it more efficiently.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Right. Can you quantify the increase in full-price March margin and the decrease in Rack?
componenttext: Right. Can you quantify the increase in full-price March margin and the decrease in Rack?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: No, we don't go to that level of detail, but our expectation is unchanged for the year.
componenttext: No, we don't go to that level of detail, but our expectation is unchanged for the year.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Next is Simeon Siegel with Nomura Instinet.
componenttext: Next is Simeon Siegel with Nomura Instinet.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Can you share your view where you'd expect the promotional levels across the channels to head going forward? Maybe any thoughts on the brand health and approach vendors are taking to their own inventories across channel? And then I know you talked about t
componenttext: Can you share your view where you'd expect the promotional levels across the channels to head going forward? Maybe any thoughts on the brand health and approach vendors are taking to their own inventories across channel? And then I know you talked about the third of Rack customers that shop full price. How large is the demographic differential between the nonoverlapping shoppers? And would you expect that 1/3 number to grow overtime as off-price continues to gain prominence?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] I'll try and take the first one. The promo level, we saw a reduction in promo level for us, which was mainly 2 factors. One is fewer promo events that we had to match. And the second being of those events, more and more of the product we c
componenttext: [indiscernible] I'll try and take the first one. The promo level, we saw a reduction in promo level for us, which was mainly 2 factors. One is fewer promo events that we had to match. And the second being of those events, more and more of the product we carry is on the exclusion list of our competitors. So for us, that's a good thing. As far as the same question was that the Rack customers that migrate over to full price, we have -- a lot of that is [ first ], opportunity there is in data. As our models become more diverse as off-price has become a bigger chunk of our business, as online becomes a bigger chunk of our business, we have more ways to serve the customer and gets us out of being a almost predominantly as our history has been, a mall-based physical store of model. And one of the great aspects of that is around customer acquisition and customer data. The Rack is a tremendous place for us to acquire customers. Now we're in very early innings of capturing the customer information and leveraging that to serve customers better. Our launch last year of our loyalty program to include non-cardholders was a big step in the right direction, but we have a lot of opportunity going forward to continue to leverage customer information better. And that migration that you bring out is one of the benefits we would see from that.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. The only other thing I would add to that is the customers between the Rack and the full price, they look very similar in terms of their [indiscernible] of their incomes and what have you. Where they tend to differ to least at what you can qu
componenttext: This is Pete. The only other thing I would add to that is the customers between the Rack and the full price, they look very similar in terms of their [indiscernible] of their incomes and what have you. Where they tend to differ to least at what you can quantify is they were younger. So that -- we worked pretty hard to try to find a way that the off-price part, what we do in off-price are -- complement each other. And you can see with the way that physically we're in stores. The most successful Rack's are ones that are right next to a full-price stores. So there is some synergy that goes with that. It doesn't necessarily cannibalize. There is share. There is acquisition that happens. But again, generally, there's some younger people that enter our brand through the Rack and that's migrating up to full price over time. Good thing.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Next is Erinn Murphy with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Next is Erinn Murphy with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, my question is on the retail EBIT dollar guidance. The range of 7 80 to 8 40, could you just talk about what's assumed from a comp perspective of the high-end versus the low end of that range? And then just staying with EBIT dollar trends, I know
componenttext: I guess, my question is on the retail EBIT dollar guidance. The range of 7 80 to 8 40, could you just talk about what's assumed from a comp perspective of the high-end versus the low end of that range? And then just staying with EBIT dollar trends, I know last quarter, you talked about brick-and-mortar margins sitting below that of e-comm margin. Is that relationship flow through in this quarter? And then longer term, how you think about working to improve the brick-and-mortar market should we stay in this sluggish [indiscernible] environment.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: So this is Jim. I'll take the first. I think from a sales perspective, we guided flat comps for the year, total sales increase of 3% to 4%. So I think this -- I think from how that plays out in terms of retail EBIT, we're right where we would expect to be
componenttext: So this is Jim. I'll take the first. I think from a sales perspective, we guided flat comps for the year, total sales increase of 3% to 4%. So I think this -- I think from how that plays out in terms of retail EBIT, we're right where we would expect to be in that zone. So really no -- nothing to really talk about there. I think in terms of the -- what you're seeing with the brick-and-mortar margins versus the online margins, I think Mike talked about it a little bit last quarter, is you've got a high fixed cost business where sales are decelerating and you've got a high variable cost business where sales are accelerating. And so we're still dealing with that phenomenon as more sales are shipping to online. And so that would play out with EBIT margins as well. I don't think anything has changed in the first quarter from where we were or where we expected to be.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add again going forward, we split out for these reporting reasons to our online and store business, but we really don't use it much internally because it's increasingly the unlocks in our model is by looking across our businesses and loo
componenttext: Yes, I would just add again going forward, we split out for these reporting reasons to our online and store business, but we really don't use it much internally because it's increasingly the unlocks in our model is by looking across our businesses and looking at the business as through our 2 brands. So we have the Nordstrom brand. We have Nordstrom Rack brand. So think about things like filling the top of the funnel and how do we get more engagement with our brand. That could be a marketing lens through our online business of, say, affiliates or banner ads or search words, but it can also be our sales people in our stores, getting them engaged with our digital tools we have and we need to look at those levers equally and not miss opportunities by putting our businesses in silos.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brian Tunick with Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brian Tunick with Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, 2 questions on the tech side. I guess, one, on the tech spending you've done the last couple of years, can you maybe talk about some of the e-comm functionality that you've added in the more recent time that you think could be the most impactful
componenttext: I guess, 2 questions on the tech side. I guess, one, on the tech spending you've done the last couple of years, can you maybe talk about some of the e-comm functionality that you've added in the more recent time that you think could be the most impactful on the business? And then secondarily, as you guys are already investors and [indiscernible], I was just curious, it sounds like Walmart is going to buy them. So I was curious on your growth initiatives between Trunk Club or HauteLook, are you guys out of the market to look for additional e-commerce acquisition vehicles?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Erik. I'll take that, and you can chime in on the second one in particular. But our e-commerce functionality, for the first quarter in general, I think you've heard us talk about it for a while now, we've had addressed the underlying architecture
componenttext: This is Erik. I'll take that, and you can chime in on the second one in particular. But our e-commerce functionality, for the first quarter in general, I think you've heard us talk about it for a while now, we've had addressed the underlying architecture to our website and modernized that. And that's different parts of our website have come online is being modernized in different times. We're about 80% modernized right now at our websites, so we're not all the way there. But as we're able to modernize portions of our site, we're able to greatly, greatly enhanced the speed with which we're able to the rollout functionality and features to our customer. So in the last quarter, both our homepage and content pages became fully modernized, and we did -- we're able to do a lot of EV testing on all sorts of features there. We had a number of enhancements in search and browse. We are right now in the process of launching a new My Account feature, which is a significant enhancement for those pretty visible customers. To really launch customers, you get a much cleaner quicker view of their order history. And the other part that I would -- I'd really call out that we're in the early innings of but we did make measurable progress is in our site performance, and that's not as sexy as a subject I'd like to talk about as customer features. But just the speed with which our site performs has improved measurably over the last quarter, and we are seeing measurable improvements in both conversion and sales from that.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: For the last part of your question, you referenced de novos and industry discussion of Walmart, I've been speaking with them and made -- had a transaction with them. Your question was geared and towards our strategy of the investments that we not make. Ou
componenttext: For the last part of your question, you referenced de novos and industry discussion of Walmart, I've been speaking with them and made -- had a transaction with them. Your question was geared and towards our strategy of the investments that we not make. Our strategy is based in the customer in trying to provide the capabilities and functionality the customer expects from us. And whether we could do that within our own team and resources or it's helpful to partner with someone or in some isolated cases, it might warrant an acquisition. We're really sensitive of how we deploy the shareholders' capital along those lines. We're not predominantly very acquisitive, but we have done some things over the years and some partnerships that have been really helpful to improve that customer experience. We have had an investment with de novos and we sell their product as well, and it sounds like there's some -- maybe some exciting opportunities for them and we'll see how that plays out.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: I will just add in the de novos, we've had -- some of our folks have had good relationships with the jet.com folks and have been in communication with them since that acquisition got announced. And we've -- [ Bonobos ] experiencing a good one for us. So w
componenttext: I will just add in the de novos, we've had -- some of our folks have had good relationships with the jet.com folks and have been in communication with them since that acquisition got announced. And we've -- [ Bonobos ] experiencing a good one for us. So what we're hearing is jet.com bought them, not Walmart and they're looking to keep those brands. So -- but right now we don't see any change in our [ Bonobos ] relationship. And in general, I think there's a overarching trend for us of needing to be more externally aware and looking for more strategic partnerships just as you've seen above the limited distribution product that we carry. We're -- our world's changing fast, and so we're curious to what's going on that other companies are approaching the retail challenges. And if there's something to be learned out there, something that can help our business by partnering up, we're willing to do that.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Next is Paul Trussell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next is Paul Trussell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: The name of your press release was that the first quarter was in line with expectations. I just wanted to circle back to the P&L and get your gauge. Was that inclusive specifically of the overall consolidated comps were in line with your view as well as g
componenttext: The name of your press release was that the first quarter was in line with expectations. I just wanted to circle back to the P&L and get your gauge. Was that inclusive specifically of the overall consolidated comps were in line with your view as well as gross margins? And then also just a follow-up on that. You have added some commentary to the guidance for considerations, and you specifically outlined that there are increased occupancy expenses along with higher fulfillment and technology costs. Can you just elaborate on how we should be thinking about that impact on the P&L?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Blake. We were trying to convey in that release is that the earnings were in line with our expectations, but the top line wasn't. And I try to make that clear in my comments as well, so I want to be really clear about that. So we fell short
componenttext: Paul, this is Blake. We were trying to convey in that release is that the earnings were in line with our expectations, but the top line wasn't. And I try to make that clear in my comments as well, so I want to be really clear about that. So we fell short of our expectations from a top line, very consistent trend we had last year so we continue to deal with in a business like that. But we are making good progress with the bottom line results in the financial model and there's more to do, and we're encouraged by that. We have a lot of initiatives that give us kind of cautious optimism for the balance of this year. And again, we try to be clear that there's no change in our annual guidance. Some of the reporting that you referred to is we're just trying to get some clarity about the new ones as for the year and the quarter because we don't give quarterly guidance, and that was the thought behind that.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Next is Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next is Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Blake, I wanted to ask a couple of questions on categories. We heard from one of your peers today that the margins in the cosmetics business are under a little bit of pressure. I'm wondering if you're seeing either any pressure on sales in the category or
componenttext: Blake, I wanted to ask a couple of questions on categories. We heard from one of your peers today that the margins in the cosmetics business are under a little bit of pressure. I'm wondering if you're seeing either any pressure on sales in the category or margins in that category? And then if you could comment on handbags, how they performed in the quarter and shoes as well, that would be very helpful.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. I will take those questions. With regards to the beauty business, it's not dissimilar from what I mentioned earlier. We have some brands that have grown extremely well, but we also have some large legacy type brands that have been off for us
componenttext: This is Pete. I will take those questions. With regards to the beauty business, it's not dissimilar from what I mentioned earlier. We have some brands that have grown extremely well, but we also have some large legacy type brands that have been off for us. But where we've had our best success in beauty is in the limited distribution brands, the more prestige kind of brands, we've had big growth there and it's given us a lot of confidence on how we can invest going forward. With regards to the gross margins specifically, we don't really have anything to report about that. There's nothing to -- no, [indiscernible] we could think of there. Then you want to know about handbags and shoes, is that correct? I think that's correct.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: So handbags, the strongest part of our handbags business, and this has been going on for a while, is the designer part. That has continued to be very healthy. There are some large brands again that participate in a lower price point and designer that have
componenttext: So handbags, the strongest part of our handbags business, and this has been going on for a while, is the designer part. That has continued to be very healthy. There are some large brands again that participate in a lower price point and designer that have been big businesses that have been challenged. And so we're -- it's created some open to buy for us to try some new thing. So we've got some catch-up to play there. So in total, our handbags, including everything, it's down more the average albeit everything else we're doing. Shoes, that's a big business for us. So we have to go speak to something pretty specific. Generally again, the designer part of our shoe business has been strong. The part that's been the weakest for us is our BP shoe department women's, which is generally represents more of an entry kind of price point, typically a bit younger and more casual in styling. We had to dig into that a little bit more and find out. I don't think that's necessarily reflective exactly what's going on in the industry because you already heard me say earlier of things like athletic and casualization has done well. So I think that really mostly on us and stuff that we can fix and sell for, so that doesn't seem to be a secular issue that we can't solve for. But generally, our shoe business continues to be very healthy.

componenttext: Yes, this is Pete. We don't really measure so much in terms of the exact percentage of business that we have. It's a little difficult to do that, and it's -- we don't have that number. I can tell you that it's growing though. We've been able to identify opportunities with a lot of vendors that are angst to try to grow a full-price business, and I think they like our capabilities in terms of the omni-channel that we present them. So increasingly, we have more kind of limited distribution product with important vendors, so that's working well. I'm sorry, what's the second part of your question?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Any trends in customer price matching? Are you seeing that come down as the industry gets a little less promotional?
componenttext: Any trends in customer price matching? Are you seeing that come down as the industry gets a little less promotional?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a little less promotional but the part that, I think, that we should be aware of, that's a little misleading that we don't quantify quite as much is just because they've moved from a literal markdown of everything, some of our competitors do a b
componenttext: Yes, it's a little less promotional but the part that, I think, that we should be aware of, that's a little misleading that we don't quantify quite as much is just because they've moved from a literal markdown of everything, some of our competitors do a buy-more-save-more program. Well, that's something we don't match. When those things are going on, it impacts our business and more online than it does in the store as that customer's kind of searching to based on price on a couple of their home or on the phone, what have you. That will be the determining factor on how they buy things. So there's still is a promotional environment out there. It's just how it's done exactly has changed a little bit. And again, we don't compete as directly with that, but we do feel some of the ill effects of it.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Pete, you talked about how, again, this more limited distribution is outside some of that more promotional environment. So the actual cadence of the promotional environment, our competition might still be the same, but the content of the inventory's e
componenttext: And Pete, you talked about how, again, this more limited distribution is outside some of that more promotional environment. So the actual cadence of the promotional environment, our competition might still be the same, but the content of the inventory's evolving and changing and create a less exposure for us and we think it's reflective in the full-price business improving as well.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017

componenttext: Next is Oliver Chen from Cowen & Company.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: You've been real leaders in the customer centricity, and the question I have is as customers expect so much, what do you think about the overall margin profile of the business? And the need to materially step margins down just as you see the variable cost
componenttext: You've been real leaders in the customer centricity, and the question I have is as customers expect so much, what do you think about the overall margin profile of the business? And the need to materially step margins down just as you see the variable costs rise? And also as you look across the competitors, who function in a very different margin structure? And it just feels like the speed to which customers expect product and the convenience factors will continue to pressure the need for you to address consumers needs. I'm curious about the multiyear perspective on that since you are at the cutting edge with a lot of the programs that you're implementing. And then I didn't know if I understood. So your lowest productivity full-line stores, like should those be closed? Or how are you -- do you feel like they're brand appropriate even though they're four-wall profitable?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Erik. In terms of the margin impacts of more speed and convenience, there is a whole list of win-win initiatives for us. Wins for the customers that are also wins for our business. And you said we're on the cutting edge. I don't know about that. W
componenttext: This is Erik. In terms of the margin impacts of more speed and convenience, there is a whole list of win-win initiatives for us. Wins for the customers that are also wins for our business. And you said we're on the cutting edge. I don't know about that. What we focus on is what are the assets we have that we can bring to bear to serve customers better. And one of the assets we obviously have is kind of 122 full-line stores to take care of our Nordstrom customers. And specifically, it's a place customers can go. It's also got people in there that can do things to serve customers better and there's inventory. We've got a lot of inventory that's sitting out close to customers. So things like buy online and pick up in store is a great service. We have that in our stores. It's growing about 50% year-over-year, and all our stores also have curbside pickup if customers want it. That's something that's a huge win for customers. It's also a win for us for a customer to come in and pick up in the store. So we're focused on what are the assets we can have. Before we get into kind of the race to the bottom of what are the things that just costs more, there is some of that but what we see an enormous amount of opportunity to do things that bolster the customer better and serve our business better.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Oliver, I'll take the second one. In terms of our smaller stores, when we look at those stores, I think we have to ask ourselves how do we feel about that store if we have to make a big investment in it? And given the amount of sales that those stores dri
componenttext: Oliver, I'll take the second one. In terms of our smaller stores, when we look at those stores, I think we have to ask ourselves how do we feel about that store if we have to make a big investment in it? And given the amount of sales that those stores drive in a given market, the answers are different. If it's a store that's -- the only store in the market, we have very measurable online sales that those stores drive. So we look at that it might be the fifth or sixth store in a market, and that will give us a different answer. And if you look at what we've done over the last few years where we have closed a number of stores that might have been the fifth or sixth store in that market and what we invested in better locations in that market would be rather the customer shop there. So I understand it's part of the question, and we look at that a lot. We think there will be some opportunities over time that we really want to look at holistically with how we're serving customers in a given market. The role that those stores play, the role that online play and how we can best serve them long term, and that will drive our decisions around our store fleet.

Or would you tell me just go do some math on why the Rack comps will accelerate? Is there something strategically you're tweaking? Or inventory opportunity that led to that comment?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Blake. In all of our businesses, we've got a number of initiatives that we're working on and there's -- they're rolling out throughout the year. I would tell you that we planned the Rack business for the trends that's been the last, let's say, 18
componenttext: This is Blake. In all of our businesses, we've got a number of initiatives that we're working on and there's -- they're rolling out throughout the year. I would tell you that we planned the Rack business for the trends that's been the last, let's say, 18 months and that's approximately flat in the comps in the stores. For Q1, we missed it by 0.9. We're confident that we can get back on top of that, meet that plan and hopefully exceed it for the balance of the year. So we think we have grounded plans and trend that enable us to be more agile and flexible and move forward as the business responds. What's happened in years past is that you tend to get optimistic that tomorrow's going to be better and we get over our SKUs in expense or inventory and it doesn't allow us to be fluid and react to the business. As Pete said, the whole subject about newness and the reason why the customer should buy something new really gets grounded in our merchants' ability to be able to keep everything fairly open and fluid. And so we have that with the Rack. Our inventories are in line. I think we have some good initiatives this year. But we look at the Rack not just -- and it's been said throughout this call from the bricks and mortar point of view, we look at it as an off-price business with -- in our NordstromRack.com and HauteLook. And when you put that together, we think we're gaining market share, and we have facts that show that but we're falling short of our plan. So we're trying to be clear with all of you on this call that we're not satisfied with these top line numbers, and we're working hard on that. And we believe that we can make some progress on that, and we have to show you that through the facts each quarter as the year plays out.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll just ask one last one. So the full-line stores down [ 6 4 ] on the comp. As we sat here today and listen to some traffic numbers from some of your competitors that are -- that have a lot more exposure being C malls that they're in, that the tra
componenttext: Okay. I'll just ask one last one. So the full-line stores down [ 6 4 ] on the comp. As we sat here today and listen to some traffic numbers from some of your competitors that are -- that have a lot more exposure being C malls that they're in, that the traffic levels are obviously at least [ hovering ] across the space right now. But we'd always look at you guys and your full-line stores as a proxy for the A malls across the country. And some of the numbers that we see come by through external beta sources through the quarter [ yes ] the traffic shouldn't be quite as bad in the A malls. And I wanted to just get your thoughts on how -- I know you guys don't speak about ASPs or AURs but -- in a month, but what do you think you need in the full-price stores at this point to say we can really get -- we can make a shot at getting these traffic numbers up in these stores if maybe there's some AUR pressure that continues in the industry?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Jamie. We look at -- we don't have pre-traffic numbers. We see a lot of the same numbers that you do. We look at transactions as a proxy for traffic, and it's been down. And the trends around that and then really consistent for the last year
componenttext: Sure. This is Jamie. We look at -- we don't have pre-traffic numbers. We see a lot of the same numbers that you do. We look at transactions as a proxy for traffic, and it's been down. And the trends around that and then really consistent for the last year plus. And so we do think that there are less visits to the mall. But what we see though is that a lot of those visits are now going to our website. People shop for things lots of different ways depending on what their needs to have [indiscernible] that day. Some of those trips in the past have converted to trips to NordstromRack.com, and thrilled about that. And so it's our job to continue to focus on investing in our business and the experiences we can provide customers across all the channels to make for a great shopping experience. And if that means they replace what see a trip to the mall with a trip to our website, it's our job to serve them well, and our target team is focused on doing that over time.

componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the Nordstrom First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
At this time, I will turn the call over to Trina Schurman, director of Investor Relations for Nordstrom. You may begin.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.Before we begin, I want to mention that we'll be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com i
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.
Before we begin, I want to mention that we'll be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com in the Investor Relations section. Our discussion may include forward-looking statements, so please refer to the slide showing our safe harbor language.
Participating in today's call is Blake Nordstrom, Co-President, who will discuss the company's first quarter performance and the outlook for fiscal year 2017. Joining during the Q&A session will be Pete and Erik Nordstrom, Co-Presidents; Jamie Nordstrom, President of Stores; and Jim Howell, Executive Vice President of Finance and Treasurer.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Blake.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. Before we review our first quarter results, I'd like to provide some context about how our business has evolved and the direction we're heading. Over the past decade, we've transitioned from being a predominantly mall-based store
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. Before we review our first quarter results, I'd like to provide some context about how our business has evolved and the direction we're heading. Over the past decade, we've transitioned from being a predominantly mall-based store business to one that is more diversified, with multiple ways for customers to shop with us. During this time, we've invested in capabilities to better serve our customers and gain market share. This fueled our e-commerce growth, increased our customer base and enabled us to expand into new markets. Through these efforts, we've added nearly $6 billion to our top line.
In keeping our customers at the forefront of everything we do, our business looks very different today. Nearly 1/4 of our sales are from online purchases compared to roughly 5% from 10 years ago. We've added more ways to serve customers through our acquisitions of Trunk Club and HauteLook. Nordstromrack.com and HauteLook are on track to be our fastest-growing business to reach $1 billion. We offer a variety of services that support our customers' needs around convenience, such as buy online, pickup in store; curbside pickup; and same-day delivery. We continue to invest in critical talent and capabilities around technology, mobile, data analytics and supply chain. Our local market assets, our stores, salespeople, product and services, represent the core of our brand. We're fortunate to have a high-quality portfolio of 122 full-line stores, with all of our comp stores generating positive cash flow. Furthermore, our stores play an important role in attracting and retaining customers. Nearly 80% of customers who shop with us across multiple channels began at our full-line or Rack stores.
We have strategically grown our off-price business, which represents roughly 30% of sales. It's positioned as our largest source of new customers, with the average age skewing younger than our overall business. About 1/3 of customers who start shopping at the Rack will also cross-shop in our full-price business. We believe this is a unique competitive advantage in the market.
Because our customer's shopping experience may be influenced by multiple touch points, it's important that we view our business from the perspective of the markets in which we serve them. We're finding that measuring our outcomes through discrete channel metrics, such as store comps, are becoming less relevant.
As we continue to head in this direction, we're increasingly looking at our business as full-price and off-price, inclusive of stores and online, to better capture the synergies of having a physical and digital presence.
Now I'd like to discuss our first quarter results. Our earnings were in line with our expectations. We reported earnings per diluted share of $0.37, which included a onetime charge of $0.06 associated with the $650 million debt refinancing in the first quarter.
Last year, earnings per share of $0.26 included a $0.10 charge primarily related to higher credit charge-backs as we transition to a change in industry liability rules. When excluding these charges, our first quarter earnings increased 19% on a comparable basis.
While we're pleased with our inventory and expense execution, we're not satisfied with our top line results. Total sales increased 2.7% while comps decreased 0.8%. This was generally consistent with the trends we've experienced over the past year.
In our full-price business, total sales decreased 1.7% and comps decreased 2.8%. From a merchandise perspective, we had strengthened our men's and women's apparel while accessories remained soft. Our expansion in full-price gross margin reflected the continued strength of our regular-price sales.
Our focus on expanding product with limited distribution helps us provide customers with the most sought-after brands while mitigating our business from the promotional environment. These efforts contributed to 100 basis point increase in the mix of regular-price sales and our full-price business.
In our off-price business, total sales increased 8.7% and comps increased 2.3%. We took additional markdowns on slower-moving items, which impacted gross margins. Overall, our gross profit rate was slightly up from last year. We ended the quarter with inventory growth in line with sales growth.
Moving to our 2017 outlook. Our plan is grounded in the sales trends we've experienced over the past year. We are reiterating our earnings per share range of $2.75 to $3, total sales growth of 3% to 4% and approximately flat comps.
As we look ahead, we have a number of opportunities to drive growth. From a merchandising perspective, we continue to focus on providing customers with newness through a greater emphasis on limited distribution and relevant product. Our long-term ambition is for continued double-digit online growth. We've been able to increase the speed and agility with which we roll out enhancements to our product pages, navigation and content.
Mobile is integral to the customer's shopping experience and accounts for more than half of our online traffic. We're continually testing and rolling out new ways to connect the physical and digital experiences. As an example, we're expanding reserve online and trying in stores from [ 60 to 50 ] stores this year. 
This fall, we have our 6 full-line store opening in Canada at Sherway Gardens in Toronto and 2 full-line store relocations in California at Westfield Century City in Los Angeles and at University Towne Center in La Jolla. We have opened 6 Racks so far in 2017 and have 11 more opening in the fall. Additionally, we're excited about our Manhattan flagship, which is on track to be completed in 2019.
We recently announced a phased approach with the men's store opening first in spring 2018.
Finally, I'd like to share that we're looking forward to having Anne Bramman join our team as CFO on June 2. She brings extensive retail experience with demonstrated success as a business partner and a steward of capital. Anne is succeeding Mike Koppel, who retired at the beginning of this month. Over the past 16 years, Mike has provided insight to the leadership team and to how we can best utilize the company's resources to produce the outcomes we aspire to achieve. Our financial standing and overall reputation have been greatly enhanced by his leadership. And first, I'd like to thank Mike for his many contributions.
I'll now turn it over to Trina for Q&A.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Blake. [Operator Instructions] We will now move to the Q&A session.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Matthew Boss with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Matthew Boss with JPMorgan.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: So my question is can you talk a little bit about the Rack? So total off-price comps in the quarter slowed to, I think, the worst trend in around 3 years. Was this the result of lower traffic? Any changes in competition? And then on the higher off-price m
componenttext: So my question is can you talk a little bit about the Rack? So total off-price comps in the quarter slowed to, I think, the worst trend in around 3 years. Was this the result of lower traffic? Any changes in competition? And then on the higher off-price markdowns, how much did this actually pressure the gross margin in the quarter?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: Matthew, this is Blake. Let's talk about our off-price business. In terms of the Rack, we had a 0.9% decrease. Our plans were to be flat. So we were really close to that. But to be clear, our plan is to beat that. Our goal is to be ahead of our plans. And
componenttext: Matthew, this is Blake. Let's talk about our off-price business. In terms of the Rack, we had a 0.9% decrease. Our plans were to be flat. So we were really close to that. But to be clear, our plan is to beat that. Our goal is to be ahead of our plans. And so we recognized that we have some opportunities. There were a number of things that our team is working on, but there isn't any one thing that I would call out. It's not dissimilar to the performance we had in Q4. We were down 0.8%. So we have seen a little bit of a softening, but it is close to our plan. And we are encouraged by the opportunities and initiatives we have for the balance of this year. In terms of the online off-price portion of it, it also just missed our plans. We're anniversarying from a year ago the strongest numbers we had. We had a 42% increase a year ago in Q1 in online off-price. We had a 19% performance for Q1 of 2017, and that just missed our plan. And you'll see, as the balance of the year goes on, much stronger numbers with our plan because we have a plan for the year that is stronger weighted towards the balance end of the year. In terms of your specifics that we've seen anything from competition or other factors, we don't have anything material that we would point out, only that we recognize this fall short of our goals, and we've got work to do to improve upon that. You had, I think, a question on the margin, too. Regarding Q1 margins, I did call out in my remarks that we took higher markdowns in our Rack business, predominantly due to some seasonal underperforming merchandise. We had some more boots and coats and other things that we felt necessitated some more markdowns. That had an impact to the overall. The overall margin was relatively flat. Full-price had an improvement in margin, with off-price bringing it down slightly.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017

Any timing issues impacting the results of this quarter? And just more broadly, how you're thinking about your SG&A growth outlook for the remainder of the year.

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Blake, and I'll start, and then I might have Jim weigh in if I missed some things. Again, we made some comments on both the slide, I believe, and in my comments that technology was a little bit higher, and that was planned. That will level out thr
componenttext: This is Blake, and I'll start, and then I might have Jim weigh in if I missed some things. Again, we made some comments on both the slide, I believe, and in my comments that technology was a little bit higher, and that was planned. That will level out throughout the year. So that had an impact from a timing point of view for Q1. There have been, throughout last year, a number of initiatives to get our SG&A in line with the business performance. We've been working really hard on that model. And we think that's starting to bear some fruit, and that showed both in the Q3, Q4 and this earnings where we're seeing improved SG&A expense management. So Jim, is there any other things that you'd call out?

headline: Nordstrom, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, May 11, 2017
